thread.title: Cassel looks to jump-start Cowboys' offense
thread.title_full: Cassel looks to jump-start Cowboys' offense

author: Eric Prisbell, USA TODAY Sports
title: Cassel looks to jump-start Cowboys' offense
text:
Cassel looks to jump-start Cowboys' offense USA Today Sports 8 hrs ago by Eric Prisbell, USA TODAY Sports © Brandon Wade, AP Brandon Wade, AP IRVING, Texas - Just one month after being traded to the Dallas Cowboys and a week since being named the team’s starting quarterback, veteran Matt Cassel continues to search for a quick on-field rapport with his receiving corps.
AdChoices “My comfort level with these guys has been great,” Cassel said.
But he has yet to throw a practice pass to the one playmaker who can make the most difference for the struggling Cowboys: receiver Dez Bryant, who has yet to participate in team practice drills as he recovers from a broken foot.
With or without Bryant on the field Sunday against the New York Giants, the Cowboys (2-3) are hopeful that Cassel can jump-start an offense that has stalled since Tony Romo broke his left collarbone in Week 2. The team has lost three straight games with Brandon Weeden as the starter.
Keeping things simple has been the priority for Cassel, 33, as he took over the first-team reps during last week’s bye week.
“I tell them, ‘You get open,’” Cassel said of receivers. “And then they tell me, ‘Just throw me the ball.’ Usually it works a lot like that. Hopefully we simplify it rather than make it more complicated.”
This already has been a celebratory past week for Cassel, whose wife gave birth to their fourth child, Clayton Cassel, on Saturday. That news continued what has been a whirlwind month for the quarterback, who was acquired in a Sept. 22 trade with the Buffalo Bills.
It remains to be seen whether Cassel will have more success than Weeden, who did not take many chances downfield. A conservative game plan restricted opportunities, but the limited passing game allowed defenses to focus on stopping the Cowboys’ running game.
Cassel, whose best NFL stretches came in 2008 with the New England Patriots and in 2010 with the Kansas City Chiefs, is more inclined to take chances downfield.
“I think you’ll see more attempted plays from him than we got from Weeden,” Cowboys owner Jerry Jones said Tuesday on KRLD-FM radio in Dallas. “You could have more bad plays, but you got the chance to have some plays 20 yards or longer.”
Starting Cassel is among the offensive changes the Cowboys will make Sunday. Rookie left guard La’el Collins will start over Ron Leary. And running back Christine Michael likely will be given more opportunities.
Giants coach Tom Coughlin said the coaching staff has studied tape of Cassel dating to 2008, when he helped lead the Patriots to 10 wins after replacing an injured Tom Brady.
“He turned in an outstanding year,” Coughlin said of Cassel, who threw 21 touchdowns and completed 63.4% of his passes in 2008. “Tall man, pocket passer, rhythm, does a nice job in there in terms of the rhythmic passing game and distributes the ball well.”
Cassel said he has never viewed himself as anything other than an NFL starter.
“I think you have to,” he said. “And I think that’s why I’ve had longevity in this league.”
Follow Eric Prisbell on Twitter @EricPrisbell .
